meeting_annotations.speaker: Justin Bahl
meeting_annotations.transcript: Uh but I would I would love that type of information.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Rebecca Garabed
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, so again, I'm supposed to stay out of this mostly, but I do know that folks collect like um the FTA cards with blood spots from hunter killed animals of all kinds. We have trapper ones for fur bearing mammals. They go for USDA surveillance programs and I don't know how much information on immunology you can get just out of like little blood spots, but those exist somewhere in USDA.
meeting_annotations.screenshare_content: Rebecca is sharing a picture of cows with large horns in a field. The image remains static throughout the segment.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Gisselle Medina
meeting_annotations.transcript: So I just wanted to make a comment related to um immunology, the very limited knowledge that I have on immunology. Uh but I think there's been work done on on bats uh given that they that they um serve as huge reservoirs of different kinds of viruses. So I I I believe that in in that sense uh knowing the immunology of such animals um where they sort of have a level of inflammation minimal enough to control virus uh replication. I think that's a a key factor that at least in the work that I do we're trying to kind of understand for instance why in the bat there is a innate immunity like type type one interferon or type three interferon highly upregulated than in other uh animals. And so this allows a better control of viral loads in bats that prevents um the animal from getting sick. So I I I think those are are key aspects that we can uh kind of try to understand for for for when spill overs happen and that we can perhaps uh use that as developing of biotherapeutics or antivirals etc. I don't know. Just a a comment.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Justin Bahl
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, I think that's a great point. Of course, you're you're absolutely right. There's there's been some nice work that's been done on on bats and and looking at the bat immune system. Um I I I still don't know how to how we use that to inform. Like it's it seems that that's why we might have a lot of viruses, they're very tolerant. Um do you think that might be a characteristic of a of a uh a reservoir host that has potential pathogens that might spill over uh for things other than bats that they can that something about their their immune response allows them to have more diverse pathogens. I I don't know. then then maybe we could use like uh like some of the stuff that's Eron's been doing with NGS sequencing and and viral discovery or pathogen discovery and if we have high diversity make a prediction about the immune tolerance, would that be the word I guess of of or or pathogen tolerance that might be informed for immunity.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ana Bento
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, I I agree with that. I think that uh it it comes from a concerted like um effort on kind of more diverse surveillance in the wild plus uh next generation sequencing. And I I really like the idea of kind of tolerance versus some sort of like immune response. Uh so in my PhD I did a lot of that with so sheep which are, you know, a wild animal where we're really trying to understand if there were some sort of like environmental cues uh that perhaps would push that spectrum from tolerance all the way to to disease type immune response. Uh and how that might actually change over time depending on uh how well um fed they are if if it was a particularly bad year um or if it's really just a kind of like a coevolution of the parasite and the host that allows them to tolerate but in the event of a of a stochastic jump that just kind of goes awry. Um but I I do agree that uh the sampling is is key uh but the sampling alone does not do it. It it definitely needs to have some sort of like field lab concerted kind of feedback loop collaboration um that makes sense to me. So I know there's a lot of people particularly in Colorado doing trying to do that uh with bats and other and ungulate species. Um so kind of really trying to understand precisely what Justin was highlighting which I do think it's it's key.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Justin Bahl
meeting_annotations.transcript: A nice way to say that I talk too much.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Ana Bento
meeting_annotations.transcript: No, not at all. Uh you just have evidence based opinions which is important.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Joyce Jose
meeting_annotations.transcript: So I have a very naive question like what constitutes a reservoir host?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Joyce Jose
meeting_annotations.transcript: Like how are we sure that there's no disease in any of these like mice or squirrels or chipmunks? because we have isolated viruses from mouse brains and they didn't obviously look sick. But um what is the definition other than bats? I know that bats don't get sick but um how do you define is a reservoir host versus it's a real host? If it's a virus replicating in a host it's it's supposed to be a host, right? So it's um or is it like you don't have a disease then it's a reservoir? I mean I would like to know more about it. I don't know anything about a reservoir host.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Justin Bahl
meeting_annotations.transcript: From so in my mind from a uh the the genetic perspective, the reservoir would host the greatest amount of diversity. So if you have so we would consider um dabbling ducks uh to be the reservoir for influenza because it has the most diverse group of influenza viruses. And even if you follow a single subtype, there's usually more diversity of that individual subtype within that host. Uh where so it's a very different type of surveillance. Don't just go out looking for uh for high path influenza but look for the and try and understand the balance of the system.
